image.caption: Collection of the U.S. House of Representatives About this object

profileText: A Representative from California; born in Whitestown, Oneida County, N.Y., October 20, 1834; attended the common schools; moved to Wisconsin in 1854; enlisted as a private in Company I, First Wisconsin Cavalry, February 22, 1862; discharged from the service as second sergeant February 22, 1865; moved to San Diego, Calif., in 1869; engaged in ranching; member of the State assembly in 1873 and 1874; appointed collector of customs of the port of San Diego, Calif., September 25, 1874, and served until his resignation on February 3, 1879; owned and operated a hotel in San Diego 1884-1891; member of the State senate 1887-1889; elected as a Republican to the Fifty-second, Fifty-third, and Fifty-fourth Congresses (March 4, 1891-March 3, 1897); chairman, Committee on Revision of the Laws (Fifty-fourth Congress); unsuccessful candidate for reelection in 1896 to the Fifty-fifth Congress; again appointed collector of customs of the port of San Diego, Calif., on March 15, 1902, and served until March 4, 1906; resided in San Diego, Calif., in retirement until his death there on May 2, 1917; interment in the Masonic Cemetery.

creativeWork.freeFormCitationText: Bowers, William [Wallace]. The bond bill. Washington: [Government Printing Office], 1896.

researchRecord.name: In the James Carson Needham papers, 1893-1936, 6 linear feet.
researchRecord.description: Persons represented include William Wallace Bowers.

researchRecord.name: ca. 1900, 1 folder.
researchRecord.description: A cabinet card photograph of William W. Bowers, who served as a first sergeant in Company I, 1st Wisconsin Cavalry Regiment during the Civil War and went on to become an influential politician in San Diego, California. The autographed photograph shows a bust view of an elderly Bowers wearing a civilian suit. Following his Civil War service Bowers moved to San Diego in 1869, was elected to the state assembly and senate, and was elected three times to the United States Congress (1891-1897).
